query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Al fine de le sue parole il ladro 2 le mani alzò con amendue le fiche, 3 gridando: «Togli, Dio, ch’a te le squadro!».
query.result:
**English:**
1 At the end of his words the thief 2 raised his hands with both his figs, 3 shouting: "Take them, God, for I offer them to you!"
**Old English:**
1 Æt ðære spræce ende se ðeof 2 ahof his handa mid ðam feohgestum, 3 cleopiende: "Nimeð, God, ic ðe ðas beacna sende!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Ahi Pistoia, Pistoia, ché non stanzi 11 d’incenerarti sì che più non duri, 12 poi che ’n mal fare il seme tuo avanzi?
13 Per tutt’ i cerchi de lo ’nferno scuri 14 non vidi spirto in Dio tanto superbo, 15 non quel che cadde a Tebe giù da’ muri.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Ah, Pistoia, Pistoia, why do you not resolve 11 to burn yourself to the ground so that you will endure no longer, 12 since you surpass your seed in evil-doing?
13 Through all the circles of the dark Inferno 14 I saw no spirit so proud in God, 15 not even the one who fell from the walls down to Thebes.
**Old English:**
10 Eala, Pistoria, Pistoria, hwi ne stentst ðu 11 ðe ðæt ðu ðe forbærne swa ðæt ðu na leng ne wunige, 12 siððan ðin sæd on yfele ðinum mæge oferfarað?
13 Þurh ealle ða circlus ðæs deorcan helle 14 ne geseah ic nænne gast on Gode swa ofermodne, 15 ne ðone ðe feoll æt Thebis niðer of ðam weallum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 El si fuggì che non parlò più verbo; 17 e io vidi un centauro pien di rabbia 18 venir chiamando: «Ov’ è, ov’ è l’acerbo?».
query.result:
**English:**
16 He fled so that he spoke no more words; 17 and I saw a centaur full of rage 18 coming, calling out: “Where is he, where is the fierce one?”.
**Old English:**
16 He ða fleah ðæt he ne spræc næfre nænne word; 17 and ic ða geseah ænne kentaure feallum reðe 18 cuman cleopiende: “Hwær is, hwær is ðe bitere?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Maremma non cred’ io che tante n’abbia, 20 quante bisce elli avea su per la groppa 21 infin ove comincia nostra labbia.
query.result:
**English:**
19 I don't think Maremma has so many, 20 as many snakes as he had on his back, 21 up to where our face begins.
**Old English:**
19 Ne wene ic ðæt Marmara hæbbe swa fela, 20 swa fela næddran he hæfde uppon his hrycg, 21 oð ðæt ðær ðære nebba us onginneð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Sovra le spalle, dietro da la coppa, 23 con l’ali aperte li giacea un draco; 24 e quello affuoca qualunque s’intoppa.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Over his shoulders, behind the nape, 23 with open wings, a dragon lay upon him; 24 and it sets on fire anyone who stumbles upon it.
**Old English:**
22 Ufan eaxlum, æfter ðære hleore, 23 mid ðam fyðrum liðende draca; 24 se ðone bryneð ðe him on becumeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Lo mio maestro disse: «Questi è Caco, 26 che, sotto ’l sasso di monte Aventino, 27 di sangue fece spesse volte laco.
query.result:
**English:**
25 My master said: "This is Cacus, 26 who, beneath the rock of Aventine Mount, 27 often made a pool of blood.
**Old English:**
25 Min lareow cwæð: "Þes is Cacus, 26 se ðe, under ðam stane on Aventines dune, 27 oft dyde lagu of blode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Mentre che sì parlava, ed el trascorse, 35 e tre spiriti venner sotto noi, 36 de’ quai né io né ’l duca mio s’accorse,
37 se non quando gridar: «Chi siete voi?»; 38 per che nostra novella si ristette, 39 e intendemmo pur ad essi poi.
query.result:
**English:**
34 While he spoke thus, and he passed by, 35 and three spirits came beneath us, 36 of whom neither I nor my leader was aware,
37 except when they cried out: "Who are you?" 38 because of which our story was interrupted, 39 and we paid attention only to them then.
**Old English:**
34 Þa he þus cwæð and he forð gewat, 35 and þreo gasta comon under us, 36 ðara ne ic ne min heretoga ne gymdon,
37 buton ða hi cleopedon: "Hwa sind ge?" 38 for ðam ure spræc ðær gestod, 39 and we þa hlyston to ðam gastum ða.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Io non li conoscea; ma ei seguette, 41 come suol seguitar per alcun caso, 42 che l’un nomar un altro convenette,
43 dicendo: «Cianfa dove fia rimaso?»; 44 per ch’io, acciò che ’l duca stesse attento, 45 mi puosi ’l dito su dal mento al naso.
query.result:
**English:**
40 I did not know them; but I followed them, 41 as one is wont to follow by chance, 42 so that one had to name another,
43 saying: "Cianfa, where will he have remained?" 44 Because of which, so that the leader would pay attention, 45 I put my finger from my chin to my nose.
**Old English:**
40 Ic ne cuðe hie; ac ic him folgode, 41 swa swa man is gewuna to folgianne ðurh sumne cas, 42 ðæt ðone ænne ðearf ðone oðerne nemnian,
43 secgende: "Cianfa, hwær bið he belocen?" 44 For ðæm ðe ic, ðæt se heretoga wurde georn, 45 ic sette minne finger fram ðære cinne oð ðone nosu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Se tu se’ or, lettore, a creder lento 47 ciò ch’io dirò, non sarà maraviglia, 48 ché io che ’l vidi, a pena il mi consento.
query.result:
**English:**
46 If you are now, reader, slow to believe 47 what I shall say, it will not be a marvel, 48 for I who saw it, hardly assent to it.
**Old English:**
46 Gif ðu nu eart, ðu lærend, to gelyfanne slæw 47 ðæt ic ðe secge, ne bið ðæt wundor, 48 forðæm ic ðe ðæt geseah, uneaðe ic me ðæs getreowe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Com’ io tenea levate in lor le ciglia, 50 e un serpente con sei piè si lancia 51 dinanzi a l’uno, e tutto a lui s’appiglia.
query.result:
**English:**
49 As I kept my eyes fixed on them, 50 a serpent with six feet darted out 51 in front of one of them, and clung to it all over.
**Old English:**
49 Swa ic ða heora eagan on ða eorðan fæste 50 and ða an næddre mid six fotum 51 foran ðam oðrum ðær fram eode and him on ðone fæðm læg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Ellera abbarbicata mai non fue 59 ad alber sì, come l’orribil fiera 60 per l’altrui membra avviticchiò le sue.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Ivy never clung 59 to a tree, as the horrible beast 60 entwined its own limbs with those of the others.
**Old English:**
58 Efeð næfre ne cleofode 59 to treowe, swa swa ðæt atelice deor 60 ðurh ðæs oðres liðe bewunden hæfde his.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Poi s’appiccar, come di calda cera 62 fossero stati, e mischiar lor colore, 63 né l’un né l’altro già parea quel ch’era:
64 come procede innanzi da l’ardore, 65 per lo papiro suso, un color bruno 66 che non è nero ancora e ’l bianco more.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Then they stuck together, as if they had been 62 made of hot wax, and their colors mingled, 63 neither the one nor the other now seeming what it was:
64 as a brown color advances before the heat, 65 over the paper, a color that is not yet black 66 and the white dies.
**Old English:**
61 Þa hie togædere sticodon, swa swa hie wæron 62 of hatan weaxe geworhte, and heora hiw gemenged, 63 ne ðæs anes ne ðæs oðres ne wæs ða gesewen hwæt hit wæs:
64 swa swa fareð beforan ðam fyre, 65 ofer ðam papan ufeweard, an brune leohte 66 ðe nis næfre swart and ðæt hwite forwurdeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Li altri due ’l riguardavano, e ciascuno 68 gridava: «Omè, Agnel, come ti muti! 69 Vedi che già non se’ né due né uno».
query.result:
**English:**
67 The other two looked at him, and each one 68 cried out: "Oh me, Agnello, how you change! 69 See that you are now neither two nor one."
**Old English:**
67 Þa ða oðre twa hine gesawon, and æghwilc 68 clypode: "Eala, Agnel, hu ðu gewendest! 69 Loca nu ðæt ðu næfre ne eart ne twa ne an."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Già eran li due capi un divenuti, 71 quando n’apparver due figure miste 72 in una faccia, ov’ eran due perduti.
query.result:
**English:**
70 The two heads had already become one, 71 when there appeared to us two figures mixed 72 in one face, where two were lost.
**Old English:**
70 Þa wæron ða twa heafdu geworden an, 71 ða ðær æteowdon us twyfigu miste 72 on anum ansyne, ðær wæron twegen forlorene.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Fersi le braccia due di quattro liste; 74 le cosce con le gambe e ’l ventre e ’l casso 75 divenner membra che non fuor mai viste.
query.result:
**English:**
73 He made two arms out of four branches; 74 his thighs, legs, belly, and chest 75 became limbs that had never been seen before.
**Old English:**
73 He worhte him twa earmas of feower limum; 74 ða theoh and ða scancan and ðone wamb and ða breost 75 wurdon ða limæs ðe næfre ær ne gesawon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Ogne primaio aspetto ivi era casso: 77 due e nessun l’imagine perversa 78 parea; e tal sen gio con lento passo.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Every primal aspect there was void: 77 two and none seemed the perverse image; 78 and thus he went with slow pace.
**Old English:**
76 Ælc ærra hiw ðær wæs unnyt: 77 twegen and nan ðæt wyrde gesceaft 78 ðuhte; and swa he ferde ðurh ðone dimman weg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Come ’l ramarro sotto la gran fersa 80 dei dì canicular, cangiando sepe, 81 folgore par se la via attraversa,
82 sì pareva, venendo verso l’epe 83 de li altri due, un serpentello acceso, 84 livido e nero come gran di pepe;
85 e quella parte onde prima è preso 86 nostro alimento, a l’un di lor trafisse; 87 poi cadde giuso innanzi lui disteso.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Like the lizard under the great scourge 80 of the dog days, changing hedges, 81 seems like lightning if it crosses the road,
82 so it seemed, coming toward the navel 83 of the other two, a little serpent, fiery, 84 livid and black as a peppercorn;
85 and that part where our nourishment is first taken, 86 it pierced one of them; 87 then it fell down stretched out before him.
**Old English:**
79 Swa swa se wyrm under lyfte geond ðone wudu fereð, 80 on ðam sumeres dæge, ðonne hi ða sunne sceal 81 ofer ðone endelenne dæg ealne gewealdan,
82 swa ða wyrmas twegen urnon ðurh ðone wudu, 83 atol ædre gemynd, ða ða hi ðone nið heardne 84 on ðam forman wife mid ðam feore gemetton.
85 ða ða ðæt attor innan ðam breostum wearð, 86 ða wearð se wyrm on ðam wife wonna and blacu, 87 and ða ða wyrmas twegen ðurh ðone wudu urnon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Lo trafitto ’l mirò, ma nulla disse; 89 anzi, co’ piè fermati, sbadigliava 90 pur come sonno o febbre l’assalisse.
query.result:
**English:**
88 The pierced one looked at him, but said nothing; 89 instead, with his feet planted, he yawned 90 just as if sleep or fever were attacking him.
**Old English:**
88 Þone gewundodan he geseah, ac nawiht ne cwæð; 89 ac he mid ðam fotum fæste, ginfæste, 90 swylce hine swefn oððe fefor asohte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Elli ’l serpente e quei lui riguardava; 92 l’un per la piaga e l’altro per la bocca 93 fummavan forte, e ’l fummo si scontrava.
query.result:
**English:**
91 The eel and the serpent were looking at each other; 92 one through the wound and the other through the mouth 93 were fuming strongly, and the smoke clashed.
**Old English:**
91 Þæt æglæce wyrm and se wyrm hine wæron sceawiende; 92 oðer ðurh ða wunde and oðer ðurh ðone muð 93 blode brehton, and se smoca styrmdon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Taccia Lucano ormai là dov’ e’ tocca 95 del misero Sabello e di Nasidio, 96 e attenda a udir quel ch’or si scocca.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Let Lucan now be silent where he touches 95 on the wretched Sabellus and Nasidius, 96 and attend to hear what is now being shot forth.
**Old English:**
94 Nu sceal Lucanus beon stille ðær he telleð 95 ymbe ðone earmlican Sæbellum and Nasidium, 96 and georne hlyste þæs ðe nu sceoten bið.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Insieme si rispuosero a tai norme, 104 che ’l serpente la coda in forca fesse, 105 e ’l feruto ristrinse insieme l’orme.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Together they responded to such norms, 104 that the serpent made its tail into a fork, 105 and the wounded one drew its tracks together.
**Old English:**
103 Ætgædere hira andswaredon ðam dome, 104 ðæt ðæt nædre hire tægl on forc gesette, 105 and se gewunda his spor ætgædere lædde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Le gambe con le cosce seco stesse 107 s’appiccar sì, che ’n poco la giuntura 108 non facea segno alcun che si paresse.
query.result:
**English:**
106 His legs with his thighs 107 clung together so tightly that in a short while 108 the juncture made no sign that it was there.
**Old English:**
106 His sceancan mid ðam þeo mid him selfum 107 wæron fæste gebunden, swa ðæt on lytlum fæce 108 ne mihte man gesion ðone sigewong betwux him.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Togliea la coda fessa la figura 110 che si perdeva là, e la sua pelle 111 si facea molle, e quella di là dura.
query.result:
**English:**
109 The forked tail took away the form 110 that was lost there, and its skin 111 became soft, and that of the other hard.
**Old English:**
109 Þa wearð ðære steorte steorra todragen, 110 se ðe ðær wæs ær, and his hyde wearð 111 hnesce, and ðæs oðres heard.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Io vidi intrar le braccia per l’ascelle, 113 e i due piè de la fiera, ch’eran corti, 114 tanto allungar quanto accorciavan quelle.
query.result:
**English:**
112 I saw the arms enter through the armpits, 113 and the two feet of the beast, which were short, 114 lengthen as much as those [arms] shortened.
**Old English:**
112 Ic geseah ða earmas in ða eaxle gangan, 113 and ða twegen fet ðæs deores, ðe wæron sceorte, 114 swa lange weorðan swa ða oðre scortnodon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Poscia li piè di rietro, insieme attorti, 116 diventaron lo membro che l’uom cela, 117 e ’l misero del suo n’avea due porti.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Then his feet, twisted together behind, 116 became the member that a man conceals, 117 and the wretch had two of them in front.
**Old English:**
115 Þa his fet, on bæc ymbwundene, 116 wurdon ða lim ðe ðe man hyleð, 117 and se earming ðara hæfde twa foran.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Mentre che ’l fummo l’uno e l’altro vela 119 di color novo, e genera ’l pel suso 120 per l’una parte e da l’altra il dipela,
121 l’un si levò e l’altro cadde giuso, 122 non torcendo però le lucerne empie, 123 sotto le quai ciascun cambiava muso.
query.result:
**English:**
118 While the smoke conceals one and the other 119 with a new color, and generates the hair above, 120 on one side and the other it strips it away,
121 one rose up and the other fell down, 122 not turning away, however, the wicked lights, 123 beneath which each one changed his face.
**Old English:**
118 Þa hwile ðe se smoc ðone ænne and ðone oðerne bewrigen hæfde 119 mid niwum hiwe, and ðone fel ofer ða heafde geedniwode, 120 on ðære anre sidan and on ðære oðerre hit of ateah,
121 se an aras and se oðer afeoll niðer, 122 ac ða leohta ne awendon ða, ða yflan, 123 ða ðe ælc under awende his neb.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 L’anima ch’era fiera divenuta, 137 suffolando si fugge per la valle, 138 e l’altro dietro a lui parlando sputa.
query.result:
**English:**
136 The soul that had become fierce 137 fled, panting, through the valley, 138 and the other, speaking, spat after him.
**Old English:**
136 Se ða gast ðe wæs geworden wod, 137 fleah ða wuduweard wudu under, 138 and ða oder him æfter sprecende spætl.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Poscia li volse le novelle spalle, 140 e disse a l’altro: «I’ vo’ che Buoso corra, 141 com’ ho fatt’ io, carpon per questo calle».
query.result:
**English:**
139 Then he turned his new shoulders to him, 140 and said to the other: "I want Buoso to run, 141 as I have done, on all fours along this path."
**Old English:**
139 Þa he wende his niwan sculdru him to, 140 and cwæð to ðam oðrum: "Ic wille ðæt Buoso rynne, 141 swa ic hæbbe gedon, on feower fotum be ðisum stige."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Così vid’ io la settima zavorra 143 mutare e trasmutare; e qui mi scusi 144 la novità se fior la penna abborra.
query.result:
**English:**
142 Thus I saw the seventh ballast 143 change and transform; and here may the novelty 144 excuse me if my pen goes astray.
**Old English:**
142 Þus ic ða seofoðan geseah 143 awendan and awendan; and her me se niwian 144 forgyfe gif min pena mislimpð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 E avvegna che li occhi miei confusi 146 fossero alquanto e l’animo smagato, 147 non poter quei fuggirsi tanto chiusi,
148 ch’i’ non scorgessi ben Puccio Sciancato; 149 ed era quel che sol, di tre compagni 150 che venner prima, non era mutato;
151 l’altr’ era quel che tu, Gaville, piagni.
query.result:
**English:**
145 And although my eyes were somewhat confused 146 and my mind bewildered, 147 they could not flee so hidden,
148 that I did not clearly see Puccio Sciancato; 149 and he was the only one, of three companions 150 who came first, who had not changed;
151 the other was he whom you, Gaville, mourn.
**Old English:**
145 And ðeah ðe mine eagan wæron sumhwæt gedrefede 146 and ðæt mod gedrefed, 147 ne mihton ða fleon swa digle belocene,
148 ðæt ic ne gesawe wel Puccio Sciancato; 149 and wæs se ðe ana, ðara ðreo geferena 150 ðe ær comon, nære awended;
151 ðæt oder wæs se ðe ðu, Gaville, bewepast.
